intro: Antiphylla arctica, commonly known as the Arctic antiphylla, is a flowering plant native to the Arctic and subarctic regions. It belongs to the family Ericaceae, which includes heathers and blueberries. This low-growing perennial typically thrives in rocky and barren soils, often found in tundra environments. Its small, white or pale pink flowers bloom in late summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and flies. The plant is adapted to cold climates and has a slow growth rate, making it a resilient component of Arctic ecosystems.
